repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - First Phase of Adaptable Program
            Loan for the National Disaster Vulnerability Reduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Phase of Adaptable
            Program Loan for National Disaster Vulnerability Reduction
            Project for Colombia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: there is existing demand at the municipal
            level for in-depth and continuous technical support for risk
            mitigation actions. Instituto de hidrologia, meteorologia, y
            estudios ambientales, institute of hydrology, meteorology,
            and environment studies (IDEAM's) work has the
            potential to contribute to the development of climate risk
            parametric insurance tools. Such tools can be supported in a
            follow-up operation, and furthermore, use the successful
            experience from other countries in that area. An in-depth
            institutional assessment as well as the preparation of a
            capacity development plan for unidad nacional para la
            gestion del riesgo de desastres, national unit for disaster
            risk management (UNGRD) will help define the institutional
            and implementation arrangements for a potential phase II. In
            terms of monitoring and evaluation (M and E), the project
            demonstrated the limits of a quantitative results framework
            (RF). It highlighted the critical need to design, from
            entry, some indicators and or an M and E system that can
            capture the outcomes produced by the project. There was a
            good synergy between this International Bank for
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) operation and global
            facility for disaster reduction and recovery (GFDRR) grants,
            targeting specific areas of technical assistance (TA) and
            delivering extra-outcomes and positive impacts around the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - Generando sinergias para la
            reducción del riesgo de desastres en el nivel local

abstracts.cdata!:
As part of the agenda in risk management
            related issues, that the World Bank has had with Colombia,
            on Jun 13-15, 2012 was carried out the Workshop
            "Sharing experiences of Colombian cities in disaster
            risk management". This publication is prepared from the
            results of the workshop aimed at sharing experiences,
            lessons learned and gaps that cities have, in order to
            effectively incorporate risk management throughout the
            planning process and the public investment. It is focused on
            5 priority areas: (i) Incorporation of knowledge of hazards
            and risks in planning processes; (ii) Inventories and
            control of high risk settlements (iii) Monitoring of natural
            phenomena and warning systems; (iv) Risk management
            information systems and (v) Institutionalism of public
            administration in disaster risk management. The workshop and
            the document was organized by the World Bank, with the
            support of the National Unit for Disaster Risk Management.
            Likewise, it included the participation of the main cities
            in the country (Barranquilla, Bogota, Cali, Manizales y
            Medellín), and technical-scientific entities at the national level.

repnme.cdata!:
Creating synergies for the reduction : the
            risk of disasters at the local level

abstracts.cdata!:
This paper states that in Colombia the
            population growth and property located in areas exposed to
            geological and hydro-meteorological phenomena are
            determinants in the increased risk. Deficiencies in
            knowledge and incorporation of environmental restrictions
            and risk conditions in planning processes and urban and
            regional planning; the inability to meet the needs of
            livelihood; socio-economic exclusion; actions such as the
            draining of wetlands and marshes, and forest loss and
            vegetation coverage; generate increased settlement in
            unsuitable areas and the growth of informal settlements
            associated with poor infrastructure, and influence in
            increasing the vulnerability to the occurrence of various
            physical events. In this context it can be said that there
            is a two-way relationship between configuration risk
            conditions and development processes, to the farsighted
            extent and that no corrective action is implemented, and the
            unknown restrictions, constraints and potentials of each
            territorial unit. In that sense, the incorporation of
            disaster risk management (DRM) in the territorial
            administration becomes a key to the safety and
            sustainability at the local level. That is, in the same
            context of development and population growth, trends
            accelerated urbanization, environmental degradation and
            conditions vulnerability; make the causes of disasters are
            changing and its impacts are being amplified. This situation
            and scenarios of potential disasters could undermine the
            efforts and progress made so far in relationship to economic
            growth, quality of life and poverty reduction.

repnme.cdata!:
Colombia - National Disaster Vulnerability
            Reduction Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            National Disaster Vulnerability Reduction Project for
            Colombia is to strengthen national and local disaster risk
            management capacity. The World Bank approved on December 15,
            2011, a restructuring to the Loan Agreement (LA) for the
            project for an increase of the threshold of the special
            account from US$2 million to US$4.5 million. The authorities
            remain committed to the project and have requested that the
            Bank reissues the amendment letter for an increase of the
            threshold of the special account. This increase will help
            the implementing agencies make progress on the commitments
            already established and achieve the investment objectives
            planned under the project period. The project remains in
            good performance status as documented in the December
            restructuring paper (RP). The current Implementation Summary
            Report (ISR) rating (February 13, 2012) is
            'satisfactory' for both the progress towards
            achievement of the Project Development Objective (PDO) and
            the overall Implementation Progress (IP). Financial
            Management (FM) for the project is currently rated as
            moderately satisfactory and procurement is rated as
            satisfactory. The undisbursed balance as of May 2, 2012 was
            US$18.37 million (16.7% of loan proceeds). This is a level
            two restructuring, and there is no change in the PDO which
            continues to be achievable. No new or additional policies
            are triggered by this proposed restructuring. The World Bank
            has concluded a project implementation capacity assessment
            of the Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development
            (MADS), which was considered acceptable to the Bank in terms
            of procurement and financial management, demonstrating sound
            capacity of MADS to implement Bank Projects.

display_title.display_title:
Colombia - National Disaster
            Vulnerability Reduction Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) :
            Data sheet
